Compression with Exact Error Distribution for Federated Learning

Abstract

Compression schemes have been extensively used in Federated Learning (FL) to reduce the communication cost of distributed learning. While most approaches rely on a bounded variance assumption of the noise produced by the compressor, this paper investigates the use of compression and aggregation schemes that produce a specific error distribution, e.g., Gaussian or Laplace, on the aggregated data. We present and analyze different aggregation schemes based on layered quantizers achieving exact error distribution. We provide different methods to leverage the proposed compression schemes to obtain compression-for-free in differential privacy applications. Our general compression methods can recover and improve standard FL schemes with Gaussian perturbations such as Langevin dynamics and randomized smoothing.

1 INTRODUCTION

Machine learning has become increasingly data-hungry, requiring vast amounts of data to train models effectively. Federated learning (FL) (McMahan etÂ al., 2017; Karimireddy etÂ al., 2020; Kairouz etÂ al., 2021b) has emerged as a promising approach for collaborative machine learning in distributed settings. In FL, multiple parties with their local datasets participate in a joint model training process without exchanging their raw data. However, communication from these devices to a central server can be slow and expensive resulting in a bottleneck. Thus, compression schemes have been widely used to reduce the size of the updates before transmission. Standard compression schemes (KoneÄná»³ etÂ al., 2016; Alistarh etÂ al., 2017; Wen etÂ al., 2017; Lin etÂ al., 2018; Li etÂ al., 2022) typically assume relatively bounded variance assumptions on the noise produced by the compressor. These schemes do not take into account the specific error distribution of the noise, which may depend on the input distribution. This can be hindering in settings where control of the noise shape can provide tighter analysis or can enable the fulfilment of additional constraints, e.g. differential privacy.

In a wider scope, different structures of the compression error have been extensively leveraged beyond FL such as in: lossy data compression for audio and music compression (Johnston, 1988; Sayood, 2017); medical imaging (Liu etÂ al., 2017; Ammah and Owusu, 2019); error control in wireless communications (Costello etÂ al., 1998); quantization in deep learning (Rastegari etÂ al., 2016) with weight pruning (Han etÂ al., 2015; Anwar etÂ al., 2017), low-precision weights (Jacob etÂ al., 2018; Jung etÂ al., 2019) and data perturbation for privacy-preserving machine learning (Abadi etÂ al., 2016). In this context, the main goal of this paper is to answer the following research questions: (i) Can we go beyond standard assumptions on the variance and ensure a particular (continuous) distribution of the compression error? (ii) What are the benefits, communication cost and applications of such schemes?

Related work. Recently, different compression techniques with a precise noise distribution have been applied to various machine learning tasks. Agustsson and Theis (2020) apply subtractively dithered quantization (Roberts, 1962; Ziv, 1985; Zamir and Feder, 1992) to ensure a uniformly distributed noise in neural compression. Relative entropy coding (Havasi etÂ al., 2019; Flamich etÂ al., 2020) aims at compressing the model weights and latent representations to a number of bits approximately given by their relative entropy from a reference distribution. Differential privacy can be achieved by ensuring a precise noise distribution, using lattice quantization (Amiri etÂ al., 2021; Lang etÂ al., 2023), minimal random coding (Shah etÂ al., 2022), or randomized encoding (Chaudhuri etÂ al., 2022). These methods can be regarded as examples of channel simulation (Bennett etÂ al., 2002; Harsha etÂ al., 2010; Li and El Gamal, 2018), which is a point-to-point compression scheme where the output follows a precise conditional distribution given the input. Refer to (Yang etÂ al., 2023; Theis etÂ al., 2022) for more applications of channel simulation on neural compression.

In this paper, we not only consider a point-to-point compression setting, but also a distributed mean estimation and aggregation setting (Suresh etÂ al., 2017), which is one of the most fundamental building blocks of FL algorithms (Kairouz etÂ al., 2021b). There are nğ‘›n users holding the data x1,â€¦,xnsubscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›x_{1},\ldots,x_{n} respectively (which can be the gradient as in FedSGD, or the model weights as in FedAvg (McMahan etÂ al., 2017)), who communicate with the server to allow the server to output an estimate Yğ‘ŒY of the mean, with a precise noise distribution Yâˆ’nâˆ’1â€‹âˆ‘ixiâˆ¼Qsimilar-toğ‘Œsuperscriptğ‘›1subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘„Y-n^{-1}\sum_{i}x_{i}\sim Q, which can then be used to perform model updates with a more precise behavior.

There are two approaches to this problem, namely individual mechanisms where point-to-point compression is performed between each user and the server, and the server simply averages the reconstructions of the data of each user (possibly with some postprocessing); and aggregate mechanisms where the encoding functions of all users are designed as a whole to ensure a precise noise distribution of the final estimate Yğ‘ŒY. For individual mechanisms, we study the communication costs of the direct and shifted layered quantizers based on (Wilson, 2000; Hegazy and Li, 2022). For aggregate mechanisms, we propose a novel method, called the aggregate Gaussian mechanism, to ensure that the overall noise distribution Qğ‘„Q is exactly Gaussian, and analyze its communication cost.

In particular, for differential privacy (DP), the above schemes allow us to consider two trust settings. First, for a completely trusted server, if the clients wish to prevent the output of the server from leaking information on their data x1,â€¦,xnsubscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›x_{1},\ldots,x_{n}, a DP restriction (Dwork etÂ al., 2006) can be imposed on the output Yğ‘ŒY. This is achieved by requiring the noise distribution Qğ‘„Q to be a privacy-preserving noise distribution. For example, a Gaussian noise can guarantee (Îµ,Î´)ğœ€ğ›¿(\varepsilon,\delta)-DP (Dwork etÂ al., 2014) and RÃ©nyi DP (Mironov, 2017). Second, when the server is less-trusted, the clients wish for the server to not know their individual datapoints but trust it to faithfully carry out some postprocessing to make the output DP against external observers. In this case, it is vital to ensure that the compression mechanism is homomorphic, and the messages sent from the users to the server can be aggregated before decoding, so that it is compatible with secure aggregation (SecAgg) techniques such as (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017) and other homomorphic cryptosystems. The aggregate Gaussian mechanism we propose is homomorphic, making it suitable for both privacy concerns of trusted and less-trusted servers.

Contributions. (1) We propose different quantized aggregation schemes based on layered quantizers that produce a specific error distribution, e.g. Gaussian or Laplace. (2) We provide theoretical guarantees and practical implementation of the developed aggregate mechanisms. (3) We exhibit FL applications in which we directly benefit from an exact Gaussian noise distribution, namely compression for free with differential privacy and compression schemes for Langevin dynamics and randomized smoothing.

2 BACKGROUND, MOTIVATION

Quantized aggregation. Consider nğ‘›n clients (nâ‰¥1ğ‘›1n\geq 1). In the standard FL setting, the training process relies on locally generated randomness at individual participant devices. In this paper, we allow the clients and the server to have shared randomness. Practically, shared randomness can be generated by sharing a small random seed among the clients and the server, allowing them to generate a sequence of shared random numbers. We will see later that the existence of shared randomness can greatly simplify the schemes.

Let Siâˆˆğ’®subscriptğ‘†ğ‘–ğ’®S_{i}\in\mathcal{S} be the shared randomness between client iğ‘–i and the server, and Tâˆˆğ’¯ğ‘‡ğ’¯T\in\mathcal{T} be the global shared randomness between all clients and the server. Given the descriptions M1,â€¦,Mnsubscriptğ‘€1â€¦subscriptğ‘€ğ‘›M_{1},\ldots,M_{n}, the server produces the reconstruction Y=ğ’ŸÂ¯â€‹(M1,â€¦,Mn,S1,â€¦,Sn,T)ğ‘ŒÂ¯ğ’Ÿsubscriptğ‘€1â€¦subscriptğ‘€ğ‘›subscriptğ‘†1â€¦subscriptğ‘†ğ‘›ğ‘‡Y=\overline{\mathscr{D}}(M_{1},\ldots,M_{n},S_{1},\ldots,S_{n},T) which is an estimate of the average nâˆ’1â€‹âˆ‘i=1nxisuperscriptğ‘›1superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–n^{-1}\sum_{i=1}^{n}x_{i}, where ğ’ŸÂ¯:â„³nÃ—ğ’®nÃ—ğ’¯â†’â„d:Â¯ğ’Ÿâ†’superscriptâ„³ğ‘›superscriptğ’®ğ‘›ğ’¯superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\overline{\mathscr{D}}:\mathcal{M}^{n}\times\mathcal{S}^{n}\times\mathcal{T}\to\mathbb{R}^{d} is the overall decoding function. The goal is to control the distribution of the quantization error as described in the next definition.

Definition 1.

(Aggregate AINQ mechanism) A quantization scheme with nğ‘›n clients holding data x1,â€¦,xnsubscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›x_{1},\ldots,x_{n} and a server producing Yğ‘ŒY satisfies the Additive Independent Noise Quantization (AINQ) property if the quantization error follows a target distribution Qğ‘„Q regardless of {xi}i=1nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ‘›\left\{x_{i}\right\}_{i=1}^{n}, i.e.,

Yâˆ’(1nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nxi)âˆ¼Q.similar-toğ‘Œ1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘„Y-\left(\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}x_{i}\right)\sim Q. (1)

A special case is when n=1ğ‘›1n=1, which we call point-to-point AINQ mechanism. In this case, an AINQ mechanism with shared randomness Sâˆˆğ’®ğ‘†ğ’®S\in{\cal S} can be performed in the following steps: (1) sample Sâˆ¼PSsimilar-toğ‘†subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘†S\sim P_{S}, then (2) encode M=â„°â€‹(x,S)ğ‘€â„°ğ‘¥ğ‘†M={\mathscr{E}}(x,S) and (3) decode Y=ğ’Ÿâ€‹(M,S)ğ‘Œğ’Ÿğ‘€ğ‘†Y={\mathscr{D}}(M,S). We do not require the global shared randomness Tğ‘‡T here since it plays the same role as Sğ‘†S. We require the quantization noise to follow a particular distribution Yâˆ’xâˆ¼Qsimilar-toğ‘Œğ‘¥ğ‘„Y-x\sim Q. The simplest point-to-point AINQ mechanism is subtractively dithered quantization, which produces a uniform noise distribution.

Example 1.

(Subtractive Dithering) For a given step size w>0ğ‘¤0w>0 and input Xğ‘‹X, subtractive dithering works by sampling Sâˆ¼ğ’°â€‹(âˆ’1/2,1/2)similar-toğ‘†ğ’°1212S\sim\mathcal{U}(-1/2,1/2), encoding the message M=âŒˆX/w+SâŒ‹M=\lceil X/w+S\rfloor, and decoding Y=(Mâˆ’S)â€‹wğ‘Œğ‘€ğ‘†ğ‘¤Y=\left(M-S\right)w. An aggregate AINQ mechanism for nğ‘›n users can be constructed via a point-to-point AINQ mechanism. For this approach to be applicable, the overall quantization noise must have a divisible distribution that can be expressed as a sum of nğ‘›n i.i.d. random variables.

Definition 2.

(Individual AINQ mechanism) An individual AINQ mechanism is an aggregate AINQ mechanism built via a point-to-point AINQ mechanism where the overall quantization noise Yâˆ’âˆ‘ixiğ‘Œsubscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–Y-\sum_{i}x_{i} is divisible, Tğ‘‡T is empty, the shared randomness is S1,â€¦,Snsubscriptğ‘†1â€¦subscriptğ‘†ğ‘›S_{1},\ldots,S_{n} which are i.i.d. copies of Sğ‘†S, user iğ‘–i produces Mi=â„°â€‹(xi,Si)subscriptğ‘€ğ‘–â„°subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘†ğ‘–M_{i}={\mathscr{E}}(x_{i},S_{i}) and the server outputs Y=nâˆ’1â€‹âˆ‘iğ’Ÿâ€‹(Mi,Si)ğ‘Œsuperscriptğ‘›1subscriptğ‘–ğ’Ÿsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘–subscriptğ‘†ğ‘–Y=n^{-1}\sum_{i}{\mathscr{D}}(M_{i},S_{i}).

Application 1: FL and Differential Privacy. The inherent sensitivity of individual data raises significant concerns about privacy breaches in the distributed setting. To address these challenges, the integration of differential privacy into federated learning has emerged as a compelling approach (Abadi etÂ al., 2016; Truex etÂ al., 2019; Wei etÂ al., 2020; Noble etÂ al., 2022).

The Gaussian mechanism injects controlled noise into computations, allowing for a balance between privacy protection and data utility. For a function fğ‘“f that operates on a dataset ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}, it is defined as

3 INDIVIDUAL MECHANISMS

In order to obtain a target noise distribution exactly, we describe two point-to-point AINQ mechanisms based on Hegazy and Li (2022) and on the layered multishift coupling in Wilson (2000), which can be used to construct nğ‘›n-client individual AINQ mechanisms using Def. 2. For geometric interpretations, we refer to them respectively as the direct layered quantizer and the shifted layered quantizer. They both rely on subtractive dithering with step size wğ‘¤w to generate an error which follows a uniform distribution ğ’°â€‹(âˆ’w/2,w/2)ğ’°ğ‘¤2ğ‘¤2\mathcal{U}(-w/2,w/2), as in Example 1, but with a random step size wğ‘¤w.

3.1 Individual Mechanisms via Direct and Shifted Layered Quantizers

Consider a random variable Zğ‘Z following a unimodal distribution fZsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘f_{Z}. Instead of having a deterministic value of wğ‘¤w, it is randomly sampled from an appropriate distribution ensuring that the marginal error follows fZsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘f_{Z}. Direct Layered Quantizer. In order to sample from a real continuous random variable, it is sufficient to uniformly sample in the area under its graph and then project onto the xğ‘¥x-axis. The construction below has been mentioned in the special case of Gaussian noise in Agustsson and Theis (2020), and studied in the general unimodal case in Hegazy and Li (2022).

Shifted Layered Quantizer. Another approach for leveraging subtractive dithering is based on multishift coupling, as described in Wilson (2000). It is based on the idea of using a sequence of shifted uniform distributions to generate a sequence of target distributions. The key idea is that the sampling from an area Ağ´A and then projecting onto the xğ‘¥x-axis is equivalent to the sampling from any horizontal reflection of Ağ´A and then projecting onto the xğ‘¥x-axis. Thus, one can can flip one side of a unimodal distribution and still take samples from the part under the flipped side (see Figure 1 with the shifted distributions).

3.2 Communication Complexity

To transmit the integer Mğ‘€M, we should encode it into bits. There are two general approaches. First, if a fixed-length code is used where Mğ‘€M is always encoded to the same number of bits, then âŒˆlogâ¡|Suppâ¡M|âŒ‰Suppğ‘€\lceil\log|\operatorname{Supp}M|\rceil bits are required. Second, if a variable-length code is used, for example, if we encode Mğ‘€M using the Huffman code (Huffman, 1952) on the conditional distribution pM|Ssubscriptğ‘conditionalğ‘€ğ‘†p_{M|S}, then we require an expected encoding length bounded between â„‹â¡(M|S)â„‹conditionalğ‘€ğ‘†\operatorname{\mathcal{H}}(M|S) and â„‹â¡(M|S)+1â„‹conditionalğ‘€ğ‘†1\operatorname{\mathcal{H}}(M|S)+1. We will see that the direct layered quantizer gives a better variable-length performance, whereas the shifted layered quantizer gives a better fixed-length performance.

For variable-length codes, it has been shown in (Hegazy and Li, 2022, TheoremÂ 4) that every AINQ scheme with error distribution fZsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘f_{Z} and uniform input Xâˆ¼ğ’°â€‹(0,t)similar-toğ‘‹ğ’°0ğ‘¡X\sim\mathcal{U}(0,t) must satisfy

â„‹â¡(M|S)â‰¥logâ¡(t)+hâ€‹(DZ),â„‹conditionalğ‘€ğ‘†ğ‘¡â„subscriptğ·ğ‘\operatorname{\mathcal{H}}(M|S)\geq\log(t)+h(D_{Z}), (4)

where DZsubscriptğ·ğ‘D_{Z} is defined in Definition 4, and âˆ’hâ€‹(DZ)â„subscriptğ·ğ‘-h(D_{Z}) is called the layered entropy. 4 AGGREGATE MECHANISMS

4.1 Homomorphic Mechanisms

For an individual AINQ mechanism, the descriptions M1,â€¦,Mnsubscriptğ‘€1â€¦subscriptğ‘€ğ‘›M_{1},\ldots,M_{n} sent from the users must all be available to the server. The descriptions cannot be first aggregated into a single number before decoding. We study aggregate AINQ mechanisms where such â€œintermediate aggregationâ€ of descriptions is possible.

Definition 6.

(Homomorphic) An aggregate AINQ mechanism is homomorphic if there exists functions ğ’Ÿ:â„³Ã—ğ’®Ã—ğ’¯â†’â„d:ğ’Ÿâ†’â„³ğ’®ğ’¯superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathscr{D}:\mathcal{M}\times\mathcal{S}\times\mathcal{T}\to\mathbb{R}^{d} (called the homomorphic decoding function) such that the overall decoding function is

ğ’ŸÂ¯â€‹(m1,s1,â€¦,mn,sn,t)=1nâ€‹ğ’Ÿâ€‹(âˆ‘i=1nmi,âˆ‘i=1nsi,t)Â¯ğ’Ÿsubscriptğ‘š1subscriptğ‘ 1â€¦subscriptğ‘šğ‘›subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›ğ‘¡1ğ‘›ğ’Ÿsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘šğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘¡\overline{\mathscr{D}}(m_{1},s_{1},\ldots,m_{n},s_{n},t)=\frac{1}{n}\mathscr{D}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n}m_{i},\,\sum_{i=1}^{n}s_{i},\,t\right) (6)

and for all tğ‘¡t, ğ’Ÿâ€‹(â‹…,â‹…,t):â„³Ã—ğ’®â†’â„d:ğ’Ÿâ‹…â‹…ğ‘¡â†’â„³ğ’®superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathscr{D}(\cdot,\cdot,t):\mathcal{M}\times\mathcal{S}\to\mathbb{R}^{d} is a homomorphism, i.e., ğ’Ÿâ€‹(m,s,t)+ğ’Ÿâ€‹(mâ€²,sâ€²,t)=ğ’Ÿâ€‹(m+mâ€²,s+sâ€²,t)ğ’Ÿğ‘šğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ‘šâ€²superscriptğ‘ â€²ğ‘¡ğ’Ÿğ‘šsuperscriptğ‘šâ€²ğ‘ superscriptğ‘ â€²ğ‘¡\mathscr{D}(m,s,t)+\mathscr{D}(m^{\prime},s^{\prime},t)=\mathscr{D}(m+m^{\prime},s+s^{\prime},t) for all m,mâ€²,s,sâ€²ğ‘šsuperscriptğ‘šâ€²ğ‘ superscriptğ‘ â€²m,m^{\prime},s,s^{\prime}.

Here we require â„³â„³\mathcal{M} and ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S} to be abelian groups (e.g., â„³=â„¤dâ„³superscriptâ„¤ğ‘‘\mathcal{M}=\mathbb{Z}^{d}, ğ’®=â„dğ’®superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathcal{S}=\mathbb{R}^{d}) so we can perform addition over â„³â„³\mathcal{M} and ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S}. For a homomorphic scheme, the server only requires the common randomness (Si)i,Tsubscriptsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘‡(S_{i})_{i},T and the sum of the descriptions âˆ‘i=1nMisuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘€ğ‘–\sum_{i=1}^{n}M_{i}, not the individual descriptions M1,â€¦,Mnsubscriptğ‘€1â€¦subscriptğ‘€ğ‘›M_{1},\ldots,M_{n}.

In federated learning, homomorphic mechanisms have several advantages. First, the descriptions M1,â€¦,Mnsubscriptğ‘€1â€¦subscriptğ‘€ğ‘›M_{1},\ldots,M_{n} can be passed from the clients to the server through a network for sum computation (Ramamoorthy and Langberg, 2013; Rai and Dey, 2012; Qu etÂ al., 2021; Rizk and Sayed, 2021), resulting in a reduction of communication cost. A simple method is to have each node in the network add all incoming signals and pass the sum to the next node. The internal nodes in the network do not need to access (Si)i,Tsubscriptsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘‡(S_{i})_{i},T. Second, homomorphic mechanisms are compatible with SecAgg (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017) and other additive homomorphic cryptosystems. We can perform SecAgg on M1,â€¦,Mnsubscriptğ‘€1â€¦subscriptğ‘€ğ‘›M_{1},\ldots,M_{n} so that the server can only know âˆ‘i=1nMisuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘€ğ‘–\sum_{i=1}^{n}M_{i}, but not the individual Misubscriptğ‘€ğ‘–M_{i}â€™s so as to preserve privacy.

The layered quantizers of the previous section do not produce homomorphic mechanisms. The reason is that the quantization step sizes of the nğ‘›n users are randomly drawn and different. Thus, the quantized data Misubscriptğ‘€ğ‘–M_{i}â€™s are at different scales and cannot be added together. A simple and naive way to obtain an homomorphic mechanism is to rely on subtractive dithering (Example 1) with a fixed step size wğ‘¤w for each user.

4.2 Irwin-Hall Mechanism

When applying subtractive dithering for each of the nğ‘›n users, the resultant noise of the individual AINQ mechanism follows a scaled Irwin-Hall distribution. More precisely, consider S=(S1,â€¦,Sn)ğ‘†subscriptğ‘†1â€¦subscriptğ‘†ğ‘›S=(S_{1},\ldots,S_{n}) to be an i.i.d. sequence of ğ’°â€‹(âˆ’1/2,1/2)ğ’°1212\mathcal{U}(-1/2,1/2) random variables and T=0ğ‘‡0T=0 to be degenerate. The encoding function is Mi=â„°(xi,Si)=âŒˆxi/w+SiâŒ‹M_{i}=\mathscr{E}(x_{i},S_{i})=\lceil x_{i}/w+S_{i}\rfloor where w:=2â€‹Ïƒâ€‹3â€‹nassignğ‘¤2ğœ3ğ‘›w:=2\sigma\sqrt{3n}, and the decoding function is Y=wâ€‹(âˆ‘iMiâˆ’âˆ‘iSi)ğ‘Œğ‘¤subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘€ğ‘–subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘†ğ‘–Y=w(\sum_{i}M_{i}-\sum_{i}S_{i}). The noise is a scaled Irwin-Hall distribution IHâ€‹(n,0,Ïƒ2)IHğ‘›0superscriptğœ2\mathrm{IH}(n,0,\sigma^{2}), where IHâ€‹(n,Î¼,Ïƒ2)IHğ‘›ğœ‡superscriptğœ2\mathrm{IH}(n,\mu,\sigma^{2}) denotes the distribution of nâˆ’1â€‹âˆ‘i=1nZi+Î¼superscriptğ‘›1superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğœ‡n^{-1}\sum_{i=1}^{n}Z_{i}+\mu with Z1,â€¦,Znâˆ¼iâ€‹iâ€‹dğ’°â€‹(âˆ’Ïƒâ€‹3â€‹n,Ïƒâ€‹3â€‹n)superscriptsimilar-toğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘›ğ’°ğœ3ğ‘›ğœ3ğ‘›Z_{1},\ldots,Z_{n}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle iid}}{{\sim}}\mathcal{U}(-\sigma\sqrt{3n},\,\sigma\sqrt{3n}). Note that IHâ€‹(n,0,Ïƒ2)IHğ‘›0superscriptğœ2\mathrm{IH}(n,0,\sigma^{2}) has mean 00 and variance Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2}, and approximates the Gaussian distribution ğ’©â€‹(0,Ïƒ2)ğ’©0superscriptğœ2\mathcal{N}(0,\sigma^{2}) when nğ‘›n is large. We call this the Irwin-Hall mechanism.

While this mechanism is simple and homomorphic (the decoding function only depends on âˆ‘iMisubscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘€ğ‘–\sum_{i}M_{i} and âˆ‘iSisubscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘†ğ‘–\sum_{i}S_{i}), an obvious downside is that the resultant noise distribution is the Irwin-Hall distribution, not the Gaussian distribution. The Irwin-Hall distribution itself is not a privacy-preserving noise for (Îµ,Î´)ğœ€ğ›¿(\varepsilon,\delta)-differential privacy nor RÃ©nyi privacy. Moreover, specific FL applications such as stochastic Langevin dynamics (Welling and Teh, 2011; Vono etÂ al., 2022) or randomized smoothing (Duchi etÂ al., 2012; Scaman etÂ al., 2018) specifically require a Gaussian distribution. This motivates the development of advanced aggregate AINQ mechanisms.

4.3 Aggregate Qğ‘„Q Mechanism

Let P=IHâ€‹(n,0,Ïƒ2)ğ‘ƒIHğ‘›0superscriptğœ2P=\mathrm{IH}(n,0,\sigma^{2}) be the Irwin-Hall distribution. We have seen in SectionÂ 4.2 that the Irwin-Hall mechanism produces a noise with distribution Pğ‘ƒP. The idea is now to decompose the desired noise distribution Qğ‘„Q (e.g. Gaussian) into a mixture of shifted and scaled versions of Pğ‘ƒP in the form â€œaâ€‹P+bğ‘ğ‘ƒğ‘aP+bâ€, use the global common randomness Tğ‘‡T to select the shifting and scaling factors according to the mixture probabilities, and perform the Irwin-Hall mechanism with the input and output shifted and scaled. In this section, we construct a homomorphic aggregate AINQ mechanism with a noise distribution Qğ‘„Q, called the aggregate Qğ‘„Q mechanism, using this strategy.

Definition 7.

We can then combine Theorems 1, 2 to give a bound on the communication cost of the aggregate Gaussian mechanism. The proofs of the theorems are given in Appendix B.6 and B.7. The pseudocode is given in Algorithms Encode and Decode in Appendix A.5. FigureÂ 4 compares the communication cost per client of the aggregate Gaussian mechanism, individual Gaussian mechanism (direct layered quantizer) and Irwin-Hall mechanism where the bounds are computed using Theorem 1 and Theorem 2. We can see that the aggregate Gaussian mechanism can have a smaller communication cost than the individual Gaussian mechanism for a large number of clients, though not as small as the Irwin-Hall mechanism. We also remark that aggregate Gaussian is homomorphic (unlike individual Gaussian), and has a noise distribution that is exactly Gaussian (unlike the Irwin-Hall mechanism).

5 COMPRESSION AND SUBSAMPLING FOR PRIVACY

5.1 Trusted server with subsampling strategy

Subsampling (Li etÂ al., 2012; Balle etÂ al., 2018) is a technique for enhancing privacy, where only a subset of clients or their data is selected for transmission. It can be leveraged to reduce communication cost while improving DP guarantees. Recently, (Chen etÂ al., 2023) introduced coordinate-wise subsampling to derive DP schemes with optimal communication utility tradeoffs. We now describe how this scheme can be improved with an AINQ mechanism.

We are interested in the subsampled individual Gaussian mechanism (SIGM) with shifted layered quantizer. First consider the case in dimension d=1ğ‘‘1d=1 with nğ‘›n clients and sampling variables B1,â€¦,Bnâˆ¼â„¬â€‹(Î³)similar-tosubscriptğµ1â€¦subscriptğµğ‘›â„¬ğ›¾B_{1},\ldots,B_{n}\sim\mathcal{B}(\gamma) (Î³âˆˆ[0,1]ğ›¾01\gamma\in[0,1]), where Bi=1subscriptğµğ‘–1B_{i}=1 if client iğ‘–i is selected and Bi=0subscriptğµğ‘–0B_{i}=0 otherwise. Let n~=âˆ‘iBi~ğ‘›subscriptğ‘–subscriptğµğ‘–\tilde{n}=\sum_{i}B_{i} be the number of selected clients and let â„°,ğ’Ÿâ„°ğ’Ÿ\mathscr{E},\mathscr{D} be the encoding and decoding functions in Def.5 for the noise distribution ğ’©â€‹(0,(Ïƒâ€‹Î³â€‹n)2)ğ’©0superscriptğœğ›¾ğ‘›2\mathcal{N}(0,(\sigma\gamma n)^{2}). This mechanism achieves the same statistical behavior as CGSM (Chen etÂ al., 2023), with the benefit that it directly ensures an exact Gaussian noise through quantization without the need to first incur a compression error independently of DP noise. 5.2 Less-trusted with SecAgg

The Distributed Discrete Gaussian (DDG) mechanism (Kairouz etÂ al., 2021a) can leverage SecAgg to achieve differential privacy guarantees against the server, which is a stronger setting than that of the less-trusted server. However, in practical implementation, it often requires a much higher number of bits per coordinate.

We adapt the experiments from Kairouz etÂ al. (2021a) which show the utility of the DDG mechanism with different number of bits against the standard Gaussian mechanism. On the other hand, using Elias gamma coding, we calculate the number of bits needed for the aggregate Gaussian mechanism and the individual mechanism using shifted layered quantizer to match a Gaussian mechanism. The results333The MSE curves for the DDG experiments are obtained with the original code of Kairouz etÂ al. (2021a). of Figure 6 are obtained over 303030 runs with n=500ğ‘›500n=500 and d=75ğ‘‘75d=75 and highlight the great performance of aggregate Gaussian. While DDG offers stronger privacy guarantees, i.e., DP against the server, it comes at a heavy cost in terms of bits in comparison to aggregate Gaussian, which is also compatible with SecAgg.

Appendix:

Compression with Exact Error Distribution for Federated Learning

Appendix A is dedicated to additional results on aggregated mechanisms with a focus on the relative mixture entropy and the details of the algorithms used in Section 4. Appendix B gathers all the proofs of the theoretical results. Appendix C presents additional details and results for the numerical experiments. Appendix D presents how the proposed quantizers with exact error distribution can be applied to obtain optimal algorithms for non-smooth distributed optimization problems.

A.4 Algorithm Decompose

The goal is to simulate an additive noise channel with a noise p.d.f. gğ‘”g that is unimodal, symmetric around 00 and differentiable knowing that we can simulate an additive noise channel with a noise p.d.f. fğ‘“f with same properties. The naive and quite inefficient way is to decompose gğ‘”g into a mixture of uniform distributions, and run the DecomposeUnif algorithm on those uniform distributions. Instead, we first decompose gğ‘”g into the mixture

gâ€‹(x)=Î»â€‹fâ€‹(x)+(1âˆ’Î»)â€‹Ïˆâ€‹(x)ğ‘”ğ‘¥ğœ†ğ‘“ğ‘¥1ğœ†ğœ“ğ‘¥g(x)=\lambda f(x)+(1-\lambda)\psi(x)

where Î»ğœ†\lambda is as large as possible such that Ïˆğœ“\psi is still unimodal. A practical choice is Î»=infx>0dâ€‹gâ€‹(x)/dâ€‹fâ€‹(x)ğœ†subscriptinfimumğ‘¥0dğ‘”ğ‘¥dğ‘“ğ‘¥\lambda=\inf_{x>0}\mathrm{d}g(x)/\mathrm{d}f(x) if nâ‰¥3ğ‘›3n\geq 3, and Î»=0ğœ†0\lambda=0 if nâ‰¤2ğ‘›2n\leq 2. We then decompose Ïˆğœ“\psi into a mixture of uniform distributions, and run DecomposeUnif. Algorithm Decompose below computes the decomposition of gğ‘”g into a mixture of shifted and scaled versions of fğ‘“f. It takes f,gğ‘“ğ‘”f,g and a random number generator ğ”“ğ”“\mathfrak{P} as input, and outputs two random variables A,Bğ´ğµA,B such that if we generate Xâˆ¼fsimilar-toğ‘‹ğ‘“X\sim f, then Aâ€‹X+Bâˆ¼gsimilar-toğ´ğ‘‹ğµğ‘”AX+B\sim g.

A.5 Algorithms for Aggregate Gaussian Mechanism

We describe the encoding and decoding algorithms for the aggregate Gaussian mechanism. We assume the server and all the clients share a common random seed, which they use to initialize their pseudorandom number generators (PRNG) ğ”“ğ”“\mathfrak{P}. Since each PRNG is initialized with the same seed, they are guaranteed to produce the same common randomness (Si)i,A,Bsubscriptsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ´ğµ(S_{i})_{i},A,B at the clients and server.

Appendix C Additional Numerical Experiments

Comparing AINQ mechanism with Quantization. Applying the shifted layered quantizer with a required compression error ğ’©â€‹(0,Ïƒ2â€‹Id)ğ’©0superscriptğœ2subscriptIğ‘‘{\cal N}(0,\sigma^{2}\mathrm{I}_{d}) coordinate-wise to an input xâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{d} that is unbounded does not necessarily lead to a bounded encoding Mğ‘€M (alternatively bounded number of bits to send Mğ‘€M). However, a classical implementation of quantization starts by specifying the number of bits, then normalizing xğ‘¥x by âˆ¥xâˆ¥psubscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘¥ğ‘\left\lVert x\right\rVert_{p} to scale it to the â„“psubscriptâ„“ğ‘\ell_{p} unit sphere and finally perform quantization on each coordinate using bğ‘b bits. For decompression, âˆ¥xâˆ¥psubscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘¥ğ‘\left\lVert x\right\rVert_{p} is shared with the decoder to rescale the quantized vector. The communication cost of sharing âˆ¥xâˆ¥psubscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘¥ğ‘\left\lVert x\right\rVert_{p} may be ignored as it is often negligible after normalizing by the dimension dğ‘‘d. To have a fair comparison with classical quantization schemes, in DP experiments, shifted layered quantization is used to reproduce the desired error distribution. Then, the number of bits used by the shifted layered quantizer is measured on the one hand and the number of bits for quantization is adjusted on the other hand such that it is always equal or higher than the number of bits used for shifted layered quantizer.

For Langevin dynamics, the number of bits bğ‘b is specified first. Each client iâˆˆ[n]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›i\in[n] scales its vector xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i} by âˆ¥xiâˆ¥âˆsubscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–\left\lVert x_{i}\right\rVert_{\infty}. The variance Ïƒb2subscriptsuperscriptğœ2ğ‘\sigma^{2}_{b} used for the compression is calculated using Proposition 2 with t=2ğ‘¡2t=2. Finally, decoding achieves a compression error of variance Ïƒb2â€‹âˆ¥xâˆ¥âˆ2superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘2superscriptsubscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘¥2\sigma_{b}^{2}\left\lVert x\right\rVert_{\infty}^{2}. As Ïƒb2subscriptsuperscriptğœ2ğ‘\sigma^{2}_{b} is known and the different norms {âˆ¥xiâˆ¥âˆ}iâˆˆ[n]subscriptsubscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›\left\{\left\lVert x_{i}\right\rVert_{\infty}\right\}_{i\in[n]} are shared, the server does some accounting to calculate the error variance of the distributed mean operation and adjusts the added error to reproduce the desired Markov chain. Refer to Algorithm 6 for more details.

Software/Hardware details. The code to reproduce the curves in the Figures below is available upon request. Other experiments were reproduced through the original implementation of Kairouz etÂ al. (2021b) and Vono etÂ al. (2022). The experiments on differential privacy applications (see Appendix C.1) were performed on a laptop Intel Core i7-10510U CPU 1.80GHz Ã—\times 8. The experiments on stochastic Langevin dynamics (see Appendix C.2) with toy gaussian data were performed on 4 cores of slurm-based cluster with 2.1 Ghz frequency. The computations for Langevin experiments required around 72 hours.

Less-Trusted Server. The Distributed Discrete Gaussian (DDG) mechanism (Kairouz etÂ al., 2021a) can leverage SecAgg to achieve DP guarantees against the server, which is a stronger setting than that of the less-trusted server. However, in practical implementation, it often requires a much higher number of bits per coordinate. The DDG mechanism relies on the discrete Gaussian distribution (Canonne etÂ al., 2020) ğ’©â„¤â€‹(Î¼,Ïƒ2)subscriptğ’©â„¤ğœ‡superscriptğœ2\mathcal{N}_{\mathbb{Z}}(\mu,\sigma^{2}) with Î¼,Ïƒâˆˆâ„ğœ‡ğœâ„\mu,\sigma\in\mathbb{R} and Ïƒ>0ğœ0\sigma>0. For any xâˆˆâ„¤ğ‘¥â„¤x\in\mathbb{Z}, â„™ğ’©â„¤â€‹(X=x)subscriptâ„™subscriptğ’©â„¤ğ‘‹ğ‘¥\mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{N}_{\mathbb{Z}}}(X=x) is proportional to expâ¡(âˆ’(xâˆ’Î¼)2/(2â€‹Ïƒ2))superscriptğ‘¥ğœ‡22superscriptğœ2\exp(-(x-\mu)^{2}/(2\sigma^{2})). Using this discrete Gaussian noise, the DDG mechanism works as follows. The input parameters are: scaling factor Î³ğ›¾\gamma; clipping threshold c>0ğ‘0c>0; bias Î²â‰¥0ğ›½0\beta\geq 0; modulus mâˆˆâ„•ğ‘šâ„•m\in\mathbb{N} and noise scale Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2}. C.2.2 Experiments on Gaussian

We adapt this experiment from Vono etÂ al. (2022). (2022) to leverage the error of compression in the Langevin dynamics. If the error of compression is smaller than the required error, then the server adds additional noise. Otherwise, the server adds no additional noise to the dynamics. The theoretical analysis in Vono etÂ al. (2022) still holds with this adaptation as it still satisfies the required assumptions on the compression operator (refer to their assumption H3).

Figure 10 above shows the behavior of the mean squared error (MSE) between the true parameter and the sampling based estimation. We start sampling after 4.5Ã—1054.5superscript1054.5\times 10^{5} iteration to be sure the chain converge to a stationary distribution. The results were computed using 303030 independent runs of each algorithm. Observe the great performance of shifted layered quantizers schemes. Indeed, all schemes using standard unbiased quantization performs worse than all schemes with shifted layered quantizers.

Appendix D Compression for Randomized Smoothing in Federated Learning

In this section, we show how the proposed quantizers with exact error distribution can be applied to obtain optimal algorithms for non-smooth distributed optimization problems (Scaman etÂ al., 2018). In particular, we highlight the link between compression and randomized smoothing (Duchi etÂ al., 2012). In the framework of federated learning with bi-directional compression (Philippenko and Dieuleveut, 2021), it allows us to derive fast convergence rates for non-smooth objectives. To the best of found knowledge, such rates for federated learning with client compression on non-smooth objectives are novel.

Federated Learning with double compression. Consider some optimization problems of the form

This distributed setting includes FL problems with â„“1subscriptâ„“1\ell_{1} norms used as regularizers to ensure sparsity, e.g. fâ€‹(Î¸)=1nâ€‹â€–Aâ€‹Î¸âˆ’bâ€–1=1nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1n|aiâŠ¤â€‹Î¸âˆ’bi|ğ‘“ğœƒ1ğ‘›subscriptnormğ´ğœƒğ‘11ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–topğœƒsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–f(\theta)=\frac{1}{n}\|A\theta-b\|_{1}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}|a_{i}^{\top}\theta-b_{i}| with Aâˆˆâ„nÃ—d,bâˆˆâ„nformulae-sequenceğ´superscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘‘ğ‘superscriptâ„ğ‘›A\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times d},b\in\mathbb{R}^{n} but also neural networks with ReLU activation function.

Distributed Randomized Smoothing. Fast rates for non-smooth optimization problems can be attained using the smoothing approach of Duchi etÂ al. (2012); Scaman etÂ al. (2018). For Ïƒ>0ğœ0\sigma>0, denote by fÏƒsubscriptğ‘“ğœf_{\sigma} the smoothed version of fğ‘“f defined by

âˆ€Î¸âˆˆâ„d,fâ€‹(Î¸)â‰¤fÏƒâ€‹(Î¸)â‰¤fâ€‹(Î¸)+Ïƒâ€‹Lâ€‹d.formulae-sequencefor-allğœƒsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘“ğœƒsubscriptğ‘“ğœğœƒğ‘“ğœƒğœğ¿ğ‘‘\displaystyle\forall\theta\in\mathbb{R}^{d},\quad f(\theta)\leq f_{\sigma}(\theta)\leq f(\theta)+\sigma L\sqrt{d}.

These algorithms rely on approximating the smoothed gradient âˆ‡fÏƒ=1nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nâˆ‡fi,Ïƒâˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğœ1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğœ\nabla f_{\sigma}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\nabla f_{i,\sigma} with sampled subgradients of the form giâ€‹(Î¸+Ïƒâ€‹Î¾j)subscriptğ‘”ğ‘–ğœƒğœsubscriptğœ‰ğ‘—g_{i}(\theta+\sigma\xi_{j}) with j=1,â€¦,mğ‘—1â€¦ğ‘šj=1,\ldots,m. Quantizers act as randomized smoothing. The idea of sampling a random perturbation Î¾ğœ‰\xi to evaluate the subgradients as giâ€‹(Î¸+Ïƒâ€‹Î¾)subscriptğ‘”ğ‘–ğœƒğœğœ‰g_{i}(\theta+\sigma\xi) can be replaced by first compressing the model parameter Î¸ğœƒ\theta with a Gaussian error distribution as â„°â€‹(Î¸)=Î¸+Ïƒâ€‹Î¾â„°ğœƒğœƒğœğœ‰{\mathscr{E}}(\theta)=\theta+\sigma\xi and then evaluating the subgradients at compressed point as giâ€‹(â„°â€‹(Î¸))subscriptğ‘”ğ‘–â„°ğœƒg_{i}({\mathscr{E}}(\theta)). Similarly to Philippenko and Dieuleveut (2021), let us consider the update rules where the subgradients are evaluted at perturbed point as

Î¸k+1=Î¸kâˆ’Î³nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1ng^iâ€‹(Î¸^k);Î¸^k=â„°â€‹(Î¸k)=Î¸k+Î¾k,formulae-sequencesubscriptğœƒğ‘˜1subscriptğœƒğ‘˜ğ›¾ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›subscript^ğ‘”ğ‘–subscript^ğœƒğ‘˜subscript^ğœƒğ‘˜â„°subscriptğœƒğ‘˜subscriptğœƒğ‘˜subscriptğœ‰ğ‘˜\displaystyle\theta_{k+1}=\theta_{k}-\frac{\gamma}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\hat{g}_{i}(\hat{\theta}_{k});\quad\hat{\theta}_{k}={\mathscr{E}}(\theta_{k})=\theta_{k}+\xi_{k},
